channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: The Great Smartphone Conundrum
item.description: The time has come—we’re going to have to choose between performance and battery life.

item.title: How Fans Recreated 'Game Of Thrones' In A Minecraft Map The Size Of LA
item.description: At a size of 59,000 blocks by 22,000 blocks, WesterosCraft is over 500 square miles relative to the characters – roughly the size of Los Angeles.

item.title: Chinese Gamer Has Spent The Past 6 Years In An Internet Cafe
item.description: There's a new poster child for China's growing problem with Internet addiction. His name is Li Meng and he has lived at an Internet cafe for six years.

item.title: The Internet 'Narcissism Epidemic'
item.description: In virtual space many of the physical interactions that restrain behavior vanish. Delusions of grandeur, narcissism, viciousness, impulsivity, and infantile behavior for some individuals rise to the surface. Sound familiar?

item.title: 24 Things You Probably Didn't Know About Beer
item.description: Thanks to hipsters, the common man probably knows more about beer and zythology (“the study of beer and beer making”) than ever before.

item.title: Was Fort Lauderdale The Site Of A Seminole Massacre?
item.description: People have long noted that there is something different about Florida. It is the only state, it is said, where the further north you travel, the further south you get.

item.title: Saving Hugo Chávez
item.description: The United States never tried to kill the late Venezuelan leader. In fact, we may have even saved his life.

item.title: The FTC Tried Sneaking A Bunch Of Teens Into R-Rated Movies
item.description: Bored now that there so many fewer trusts to bust, the Federal Trade Commission got together with a bunch of its teen friends and tried sneaking into some R-rated movies, only to discover that theaters are way less cool about that than they used to be.

item.title: How Identity Thieves Could Steal Your Tax Refund
item.description: More than a million Americans have their tax refunds stolen by identity thieves every year — and that number is skyrocketing.

item.title: The 5 Freakiest (And Obscure) Sci-Fi Islands You Don’t Want To Visit
item.description: Not every imagined island getaway is a destination worth spending your vacation—or even ten minutes—unless being eaten by a crocodile with tentacles is your idea of fun.

item.title: What The Internet Looked Like In 1995
item.description: In this episode of "Computer Chronicles," the team goes in-depth on "The Internet," a trendy topic in 1995.

item.title: Spring Break Forever: 1920s France Meets 2013 Florida
item.description: The promise of spring break goes way back in American culture, predating "Girls Gone Wild" and the hushed pledge that what happens in Cancun stays in Cancun.

item.title: Next-Gen $100 Bills Prove Hard To Make, Easy To Fake
item.description: Touted as the world’s most-advanced currency, the next-generation $100 bill suffers from creasing and blank strips during printing and has yet to be circulated. Meanwhile, the technology available to counterfeiters is catching up.

item.title: Boxes Sealed With ATHEIST Tape Were 'Lost' By USPS 10x More Often Than Ones Without It
These Six Regular People Just Got Invited To Use Google Glass
item.description: Google has announced that they'll be sending out thousands of invites telling lucky #ifihadglass campaign winners that they can buy the Google Glass device for $1,500.

item.title: Why You Should Get Up Early
item.description: The case for starting your day in the dark.

item.title: The Company That Fought To Make Paying Your Taxes Harder
item.description: Imagine filing your income taxes in five minutes — and for free. You'd open up a pre-filled return, see what the government thinks you owe, make any needed changes and be done. The miserable annual IRS shuffle, gone. So why hasn't it become a reality?

item.title: Here's What Political Science Actually Does, Congress
item.description: Congress just cut funding for political science because they don’t understand the good it does. Here are four excellent examples.

item.title: What It's Like Being The First Game Developer In Your Entire Country
item.description: Leti Games is the only game studio in Ghana. “We are on the verge of creating not just a game company, but an entire industry,” says a founder.

item.title: Hipsters Panic When Confronted With A Guy Fieri Restaurant In Brooklyn
item.description: Trendy Brooklynites love to grab an ironic dining experience at Guy Fieri’s restaurant in Times Square, but what would they think if Guy made plans to open a branch in their neighborhood?

item.title: Why Do Cicadas Spend So Much Time Underground?
item.description: Seventeen years is a long time to hang out underground. It’s long enough for Bill Pullman to go from an awesome fictional president to an awful one. Why do cicadas spend so much time out of sight and out of mind?

item.title: 10 Movies We Can't Believe Have Merchandise Tie-Ins
item.description: When "Being John Malkovich" was released in a limited-edition VHS collector’s set (yep, they used to do that), Polygram USA Video was looking for something special to lure consumers to the package.

item.title: Designers Cram Entire Hotel Room Into A Suitcase
item.description: A portable hotel room design packs down into a trunk, and then pops up into a sleeping area and work space.

item.title: Drunk Man Buys Enormous Snake, Which Tries To Eat His Friend
item.description: Never drink and drive. Also, never drink and purchase a potentially deadly animal.

item.title: Jane Goodall's Junk Science
item.description: Last week famed primatologist Jane Goodall was found to have plagiarized parts of her new book, but a deeper look reveals a work plagued by rampant copying, obvious errors, and ominous junk science.

item.title: What It's LIke To Have Gay Parents
item.description: People often asked me, "Do you think not having a father changed you?”

item.title: Has The Met Museum Been Cheating On Admission Prices?
item.description: The Met asks you to pay a “recommended” admissions fee of $25 USD. Just what that “recommended” really means is at the heart of a class action lawsuit coming before New York this month prompting the question: are all “admission” fees a form of cheating?

item.title: Hackers Create An Amazing, Illegal Portrait Of The Internet
item.description: Someone hacked almost half a million devices around the world. Why? They wanted to see what the Internet looked like.

item.title: The Life And Death Of The Hacker Who Was Supposed To Be The Next Mark Zuckerberg
item.description: Ilya Zhitomirskiy was supposed to be the next Mark Zuckerberg. And then everything fell apart.

item.title: How To Steal Soda From A Vending Machine With A Measuring Tape
item.description: The title says it all.

item.title: Having Herpes Is Even Worse Than You Thought
item.description: A study in the journal "Neurology" brings the surprising news that having herpes could be even worse than you think it is.
